p: These different definitions and limitations were visually observed. For instance, Figure 10 displays either a single cluster composed of 4 epidemic nodes –the NT version of a cluster (red pentagon)–, or, in the SS version, 6 clusters (the 6 epidemic nodes that include, each, two or more cases). While compatible with both the SS and NT approaches, the bio-geo-temporal model was more informative: if two disease clusters displayed identical SS indices (e.g., Moran’s I) or identical NT cluster coefficients [61], the bio-geo-temporal approach could distinguish them in terms of continuity, long-range connectivity, proximity, and/or transmission cycle.
